awd_titl_txt: Antarctica as a Model System for Responses of Terrestrial Carbon Balance to Warming
awd_abstract_narration:
The main goal of this study is to investigate carbon transformation processes and the microbial communities that are responsible for such transformations in soils of the Antarctic Peninsula.  The study will examine net ecosystem carbon balance among soils with different exposer ages that have had been uncovered by retreating glaciers.  The study will use a novel technique to identify individual members of the soil microbial community that are active versus those that are not active (perhaps cold-preserved) in order to better understand the fundamental processes of community succession in the Antarctic environment and whether continued warming could lead to community shifts in the active portion of the communities. Several graduate and undergraduate students are supported on this project. Findings of the research will be disseminated to the scientific community through publications in peer-reviewed journals and through seminars/lectures, and to the broader community through science presentations to the local community and through lectures in elementary schools (including Skype).
 
The study will focus on a deglaciated sere on the western Antarctic Peninsula, which offers a strong gradient in primary productivity and a platform for investigating soil carbon dynamics specific to the Antarctic maritime setting. The experiment will use open-top chambers paired with control plots, arrayed along the productivity gradient. Carbon fluxes (incoming and outgoing) will be determined in all the plots using infrared gas analysis in experimental chambers. This study will also use heavy water (water enriched with 18O) to identify active versus inactive soil microbial members in incubations and experiments. Findings from this project will advance research in plant and soil microbial ecology, ecosystem modeling and advance understanding of the potential changes in the Antarctic ecosystem due to warming conditions.

por.por_cntn:
Soils contain roughly three to four times the amount of carbon that is in the atmosphere. Hence, small changes in the terrestrial carbon cycle could have major repercussions for the pace of climate change.  It is unclear whether warming would increase respiratory losses of carbon (and cause a positive feedback to warming) or whether warming promotes more photosynthetic uptake of carbon through greater plant growth (and hence cause a negative feedback to warming). The tractable terrestrial ecosystem of Antarctica enables us to determine the contributions of microbes and plants to observed ecosystem level fluxes ? a feat possible in no other natural ecosystem.

We used a glacier foreland to examine how warming affects plant and microbial responses along a natural gradient in plant productivity, with no plants nearest the glacier (youngest soils, site 1) and lush sites farther away (i.e., 100% vegetated with lichens, mosses and both species of vascular plants native to Antarctica, site 4). We used open-top chambers to warm the air and soil temperatures, a method shown to be successful in polar environments (Arctic and Antarctic).

We measured uptake and release of carbon along the gradient and how warming altered these two opposing fluxes. We also conducted lab experiments and field-incubations to gain a better understanding of the physiology of plants and microbes. For the microbes we used a cutting-edge approach to examine microbial growth at the scale of individual taxa (?species?) called quantitative stable isotope probing. Using this technique, we were the first in Antarctica to examine growth of moss-associated bacteria.

We found that the youngest site (nearest the glacier) responded positively to warming: we found increased microbial growth and increased carbon uptake. In fact, warming resulted in this site becoming a net sink of carbon even though this site lacked plants. The contribution of microbes to the carbon cycle, especially in recently deglaciated soils, can thus not be ignored. This finding was consistent with our quantitative stable isotope probing field experiment ? we found that members of the Cyanobacteria (microbial ?plants?) in particular grew more with warming and that Cyanobacteria were more ?species?-rich. This could also indicate increased growth of soil algae. We also found microbes that grew in the warmed plots, but not in the control plots at the same site and vice versa. We would not have known this if we had sequenced the soils the traditional way. Lastly, we found that microbial communities between sites 1 and 4 were very distinct, likely because at site 4 these associated with moss peatbanks, whereas those at site 1 were free-living organisms.

At the opposite end of the plant productivity spectrum, the densest vegetated site, we found that warming had the opposite effect on the carbon cycle: warming reduced uptake of carbon to such a degree that on occasion the ecosystem switched to a net carbon source. Our lab experiments indicated that mosses increase respiration in response to warming, and their physiology was such that higher light levels were needed for mosses to have net uptake of carbon. The photosynthetic responses of mosses varied for the different species, however. Additionally, lower relative humidity caused by higher air temperatures could have also contributed to the reductions in carbon uptake, as moss physiology is strongly dependent on water availability.

Findings from our research suggest that short-term warming will be beneficial for recently deglaciated soils, where warming will lead to an increase in carbon uptake by microbial photosynthesizers. In contrast, warming in older, vegetated sites, which form the largest terrestrial carbon sink in Antarctica, will lead to a reduction in carbon uptake. Because warming affected moss species differently, we can expect shifts in species composition as the climate continues to warm. Longer-term studies are needed to determine whether there is thermal acclimation of plants and soil microbes or changes to the community composition, which could alter our conclusions.
